title: 1 Samuel Chapter 20 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Samuel chapter 20 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 20 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Samuel Chapter 20.

questions.question: Who did David speak to when he fled from Naioth in Ramah?
options: Jonathan
Saul
Abner
Samuel
questions.correctAnswer: Jonathan
questions.explanation: David came and spoke before Jonathan as stated in 1 Samuel 20:1.

questions.question: What did David ask Jonathan in 1 Samuel 20?
options: What have I done? What is my sin before thy father?
Where is the king?
How can I defeat my enemies?
Will you help me become king?
questions.correctAnswer: What have I done? What is my sin before thy father?
questions.explanation: David asked Jonathan what his iniquity or sin was before Saul that caused him to seek David's life, as in 1 Samuel 20:1.

questions.question: What did Jonathan promise David he would do for him?
options: Whatsoever thy soul desireth, I will even do it for thee
I will make you king
I will send you gifts
I will speak to the king about you
questions.correctAnswer: Whatsoever thy soul desireth, I will even do it for thee
questions.explanation: Jonathan told David he would do whatever his soul desired, as recorded in 1 Samuel 20:4.

questions.question: When was the new moon that David referred to in his plan to hide?
options: The next day
After three weeks
At the end of the month
In two days
questions.correctAnswer: The next day
questions.explanation: David said 'to morrow is the new moon', meaning the next day, in 1 Samuel 20:5.

questions.question: What excuse did Jonathan say David should use if Saul asked about his absence?
options: David asked leave to go to Bethlehem for a yearly sacrifice
David was sick
David was on a mission for the king
David was traveling to another city
questions.correctAnswer: David asked leave to go to Bethlehem for a yearly sacrifice
questions.explanation: Jonathan told David to say he went to Bethlehem for a yearly family sacrifice, according to 1 Samuel 20:6.

questions.question: What did Jonathan say he would do if his father planned evil against David?
options: He would warn David and send him away
He would join his father
He would ignore it
He would fight his father
questions.correctAnswer: He would warn David and send him away
questions.explanation: Jonathan promised to tell David if Saul planned evil, and send him away so he might go in peace, as in 1 Samuel 20:13.

questions.question: What covenant did Jonathan make with David?
options: A covenant of the LORD between the house of David and Jonathan
A covenant to divide the kingdom
A covenant to never fight
A covenant to share wealth
questions.correctAnswer: A covenant of the LORD between the house of David and Jonathan
questions.explanation: Jonathan made a covenant with the house of David, saying the LORD would require it at the hand of David's enemies, as stated in 1 Samuel 20:16.

questions.question: How did Jonathan express his love for David?
options: He caused David to swear again because he loved him as his own soul
He gave David his sword
He invited David to the palace
He gave David gifts
questions.correctAnswer: He caused David to swear again because he loved him as his own soul
questions.explanation: Jonathan caused David to swear again because he loved him as he loved his own soul, found in 1 Samuel 20:17.

questions.question: What signal did Jonathan plan to use to inform David about Saul's intentions?
options: Shooting three arrows and sending a lad to find them
Lighting a fire on a hill
Sending a messenger with a letter
Blowing a trumpet
questions.correctAnswer: Shooting three arrows and sending a lad to find them
questions.explanation: Jonathan planned to shoot three arrows and send a lad to find them as a signal to David, as described in 1 Samuel 20:20-21.

questions.question: True or False: Saul immediately spoke to Jonathan about David's absence on the day of the new moon.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Saul did not speak any word that day because he thought something was wrong with David, as stated in 1 Samuel 20:26.

questions.question: True or False: Jonathan defended David to his father Saul and questioned why David should be slain.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jonathan asked Saul why David should be slain and what he had done, found in 1 Samuel 20:32.

questions.question: True or False: Jonathan was angry and did not eat on the second day of the month because he was grieved for David.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jonathan was angry and did not eat on the second day because Saul had done shame to David, as in 1 Samuel 20:34.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 1 Samuel 20:41: 'And as soon as the lad was gone, David arose out of a place toward the south, and fell on his face to the ground, and bowed himself three times: and they ______ one another, and wept one with another, until David exceeded.'
options: kissed
praised
greeted
embraced
questions.correctAnswer: kissed
questions.explanation: The verse says they kissed one another and wept, showing their deep friendship, in 1 Samuel 20:41.

questions.question: Who sat by Saul's side during the king's meal when David's place was empty?
options: Abner
Jonathan
David
Samuel
questions.correctAnswer: Abner
questions.explanation: Abner sat by Saul's side as Jonathan arose and David's place was empty, as in 1 Samuel 20:25.

questions.question: What did Jonathan say should be between him and David forever?
options: The LORD
A sword
A covenant
A promise
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Jonathan said 'the LORD be between thee and me for ever' in reference to their covenant, as in 1 Samuel 20:23.

medium.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 20 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Samuel Chapter 20 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on 1 Samuel 20, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God during times of danger?
options: God’s protection is assured when we trust Him and seek wise counsel.
We should avoid all difficulties by hiding from them.
It is best to confront danger without any preparation.
God does not care about personal struggles.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s protection is assured when we trust Him and seek wise counsel.
questions.explanation: David fled for his life but sought Jonathan’s help and trusted God's providence (1 Samuel 20:1-3, 9-13). This shows that trusting God and seeking godly counsel is vital in trials.

questions.question: How does Jonathan’s behavior toward David in 1 Samuel 20 teach us about loyalty and love among believers?
options: True friendship involves selfless loyalty, even in difficult times.
Friends should only support when it benefits them.
Loyalty is less important than obeying authority blindly.
Love requires ignoring dangerous situations.
questions.correctAnswer: True friendship involves selfless loyalty, even in difficult times.
questions.explanation: Jonathan made a covenant with David, showing deep love and loyalty despite his father’s hostility (1 Samuel 20:14-17, 41-42). This models selfless friendship.

questions.question: When David asked Jonathan about his father’s intentions, what spiritual discipline is demonstrated by Jonathan’s plan to communicate God’s will?
options: Prayerful discernment and clear communication.
Ignoring difficult conversations.
Making assumptions without evidence.
Avoiding all conflict.
questions.correctAnswer: Prayerful discernment and clear communication.
questions.explanation: Jonathan prayed to the LORD and devised a clear sign system to inform David about Saul’s attitude (1 Samuel 20:12-23). This shows reliance on prayer and wise communication.

questions.question: Based on Jonathan’s response to Saul’s anger, what biblical principle about standing for righteousness under pressure is taught?
options: Faithfulness to God and friends may require courage against opposition.
Avoid all confrontation to keep peace.
Ignore injustice to stay safe.
Rebellion is acceptable when angry.
questions.correctAnswer: Faithfulness to God and friends may require courage against opposition.
questions.explanation: Jonathan defended David before Saul and was willing to suffer his father’s anger (1 Samuel 20:30-34), showing courage in standing for righteousness.

questions.question: How does David’s willingness to swear an oath to Jonathan demonstrate the importance of integrity in relationships?
options: Integrity builds trust and solidifies covenants between believers.
Oaths are unnecessary in godly relationships.
Promises made under pressure need not be kept.
Trust is based only on feelings.
questions.correctAnswer: Integrity builds trust and solidifies covenants between believers.
questions.explanation: David and Jonathan swore to each other, confirming their covenant by invoking the LORD’s name, underscoring the value of integrity (1 Samuel 20:3, 16-17, 41-42).

questions.question: What practical lesson about patience and waiting on God is illustrated by David hiding for three days as planned with Jonathan?
options: Patience and obedience to God’s timing are essential during trials.
We should act impulsively without planning.
Ignoring God’s guidance leads to better outcomes.
Hiding is always the best solution.
questions.correctAnswer: Patience and obedience to God’s timing are essential during trials.
questions.explanation: David obeyed Jonathan’s plan to hide for three days and wait for the signal, demonstrating patient trust in God’s timing (1 Samuel 20:5, 19, 24).

questions.question: Based on 1 Samuel 20, how can believers apply the example of Jonathan’s kindness to David in their own church life?
options: Show ongoing kindness and support to fellow believers, especially in hardship.
Kindness should be reserved only for close friends.
Avoid involvement in others' struggles.
Kindness is optional and not important.
questions.correctAnswer: Show ongoing kindness and support to fellow believers, especially in hardship.
questions.explanation: Jonathan asked David to continue showing kindness to his family forever, highlighting the importance of lasting support among believers (1 Samuel 20:14-15).

questions.question: True or False: Jonathan attempted to deceive his father Saul by hiding the truth about David’s absence.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jonathan honestly told Saul that David had asked permission to go to Bethlehem for a family sacrifice (1 Samuel 20:27-29).

questions.question: How does David’s emotional farewell with Jonathan teach us about expressing genuine feelings in godly friendships?
options: Honest emotional expression strengthens bonds and honors God.
Emotions should always be hidden to appear strong.
Friendship is only about practical help.
Tears indicate weakness and should be avoided.
questions.correctAnswer: Honest emotional expression strengthens bonds and honors God.
questions.explanation: David and Jonathan wept and kissed, showing deep love and grief, illustrating that heartfelt emotion is part of godly friendship (1 Samuel 20:41).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jonathan and David’s covenant was made in the name of the ____, signifying a solemn and spiritual commitment.
options: LORD
king
family
friendship
questions.correctAnswer: LORD
questions.explanation: The covenant between Jonathan and David was sworn in the name of the LORD, indicating a sacred, divine commitment (1 Samuel 20:42).

questions.question: What does Saul’s reaction to David’s absence reveal about the consequences of harboring anger and jealousy?
options: Anger and jealousy can lead to broken family relationships and violence.
It is acceptable to act on anger without questioning motives.
Jealousy should be ignored as harmless.
Anger always leads to positive outcomes.
questions.correctAnswer: Anger and jealousy can lead to broken family relationships and violence.
questions.explanation: Saul’s anger towards Jonathan and violent threats demonstrate how jealousy damages relationships (1 Samuel 20:30-33).

questions.question: How does Jonathan’s use of a sign involving arrows illustrate the importance of clear communication in difficult situations?
options: Clear, agreed-upon signals prevent misunderstanding and aid safety.
Communication is unnecessary during danger.
Ambiguity is better for protecting secrets.
Signals should be confusing to outsiders.
questions.correctAnswer: Clear, agreed-upon signals prevent misunderstanding and aid safety.
questions.explanation: Jonathan arranged a specific sign with arrows to inform David of Saul’s intentions, exemplifying wise communication (1 Samuel 20:19-23).

questions.question: True or False: David was willing to accept death if he had sinned against Jonathan, showing accountability in friendship.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: David told Jonathan to slay him if he had iniquity, demonstrating accountability and integrity (1 Samuel 20:8).

questions.question: What does the repeated swearing between David and Jonathan teach about the value of vows in maintaining godly relationships?
options: Vows strengthen trust and commitment when made before God.
Vows are unnecessary and unbiblical.
Promises can be broken without consequence.
God does not care about human oaths.
questions.correctAnswer: Vows strengthen trust and commitment when made before God.
questions.explanation: Jonathan caused David to swear again because of love, showing the seriousness of vows in godly friendship (1 Samuel 20:17).

questions.question: How can believers apply the example of Jonathan’s grief over his father’s actions to dealing with family conflicts biblically?
options: Express sorrow over injustice while maintaining love and prayer for family.
Ignore family wrongs to keep peace at any cost.
Retaliate quickly and harshly.
Avoid difficult family relationships entirely.
questions.correctAnswer: Express sorrow over injustice while maintaining love and prayer for family.
questions.explanation: Jonathan was grieved by Saul’s shameful actions but did not abandon his role, modeling godly sorrow (1 Samuel 20:34).

questions.question: What does David’s act of bowing and kissing Jonathan before they parted teach about humility and gratitude in relationships?
options: Humility and gratitude deepen relationships and honor God.
Pride strengthens friendships.
Gratitude is unnecessary among close friends.
Physical expressions are inappropriate.
questions.correctAnswer: Humility and gratitude deepen relationships and honor God.
questions.explanation: David bowed and kissed Jonathan, showing humble gratitude for their friendship (1 Samuel 20:41).

hard.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 20 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Samuel Chapter 20.

questions.question: In 1 Samuel 20, what method do David and Jonathan devise to communicate the attitude of Saul towards David's safety?
options: Jonathan shoots three arrows and sends a boy to retrieve them
Jonathan sends a messenger to Saul to ask directly
David sends a letter to Jonathan's father
Jonathan uses a secret code in a song
questions.correctAnswer: Jonathan shoots three arrows and sends a boy to retrieve them
questions.explanation: In verses 20-22, Jonathan shoots three arrows on the side of a stone and sends a boy to fetch them. Depending on where the arrows fall, it signals whether Saul intends harm or peace toward David.

questions.question: What covenantal language in 1 Samuel 20 emphasizes the deep bond between Jonathan and David, reflecting ancient Near Eastern treaty forms?
options: Jonathan says he loves David as his own soul and makes him swear
Jonathan offers David a gift of gold
David is made a servant in Jonathan’s household
Jonathan promises to marry David’s sister
questions.correctAnswer: Jonathan says he loves David as his own soul and makes him swear
questions.explanation: Verse 17 shows Jonathan making David swear again because he loved him as his own soul, reflecting covenantal loyalty and the Near Eastern practice of formal oaths to bind relationships.

questions.question: How does the narrative structure in 1 Samuel 20 foreshadow David’s future kingship in light of Jonathan’s loyalty and Saul’s hostility?
options: The covenant between Jonathan and David anticipates a peaceful transition of power
Saul’s anger and attempt to kill Jonathan indicates a broken monarchy
David’s hiding symbolizes his exile before becoming king
Jonathan’s protection of David portrays a typology of faithful leadership
questions.correctAnswer: David’s hiding symbolizes his exile before becoming king
questions.explanation: David’s concealment (verse 24) foreshadows the period of exile he must endure before kingship, while Jonathan’s loyalty contrasts with Saul’s hostility, highlighting the divided monarchy theme.

questions.question: What cultural significance does the "new moon" festival hold in 1 Samuel 20, and how does it affect David’s plans?
options: It is a time when the king and court gather to eat, making David’s absence noticeable
It is a day of fasting and prayer, so David plans to fast
It is when all men go to war, so David must hide
It marks the beginning of a harvest feast, so David attends it
questions.correctAnswer: It is a time when the king and court gather to eat, making David’s absence noticeable
questions.explanation: Verse 5 notes that the new moon is when the king sits at meat, so David’s absence during this festival would be conspicuous, driving the plot of Jonathan’s plan to signal Saul’s intentions.

questions.question: Identify the Hebrew word for 'covenant' implied in Jonathan’s agreement with David, and explain its theological significance in the ancient Israelite context.
options: Berith, indicating a solemn binding agreement often sealed by a sacrifice
Chesed, highlighting loving-kindness and mercy
Shalom, representing peace and completeness
Emet, meaning truth or faithfulness
questions.correctAnswer: Berith, indicating a solemn binding agreement often sealed by a sacrifice
questions.explanation: The term 'covenant' (berith) in verse 16 is the Hebrew word used for solemn agreements, underscoring the seriousness of Jonathan and David’s pact, reflecting Israelite covenant traditions.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Jonathan’s dialogue to David in verses 12-13, especially in the phrase 'The LORD do so and much more to Jonathan'?
options: Imprecatory oath invoking divine witness
Metaphorical parallelism emphasizing protection
Chiasm structuring the promise and warning
Typological foreshadowing of messianic covenant
questions.correctAnswer: Imprecatory oath invoking divine witness
questions.explanation: Jonathan invokes the LORD as witness with an imprecatory oath (verse 12), a common Hebrew literary device to solemnize promises and warnings.

questions.question: From a historical-critical perspective, what does Saul’s reaction to Jonathan’s defense of David (1 Samuel 20:30-31) reveal about Saul’s kingship and political paranoia?
options: His insecurity leads to violent attempts to eliminate perceived rivals
He is confident and secure in his throne
He is indifferent to family loyalty
He seeks peaceful reconciliation with David
questions.correctAnswer: His insecurity leads to violent attempts to eliminate perceived rivals
questions.explanation: Saul’s anger and attempt to kill Jonathan (verse 33) illustrate his paranoia and insecurity as king, common themes in ancient Near Eastern monarchies facing internal threats.

questions.question: How does the personal relationship between Jonathan and David in this chapter reflect broader biblical themes of covenantal friendship and loyalty?
options: Their covenant models selfless friendship based on mutual loyalty under God
It is a political alliance to overthrow Saul
Jonathan uses David for personal gain
Their relationship is purely strategic with no emotional bond
questions.correctAnswer: Their covenant models selfless friendship based on mutual loyalty under God
questions.explanation: Verses 16-17 emphasize the covenant and love between Jonathan and David, exemplifying biblical ideals of friendship and loyalty founded in the LORD.

questions.question: What is the significance of David bowing three times and kissing Jonathan before they part (1 Samuel 20:41) in the context of ancient Near Eastern customs?
options: It expresses deep respect, affection, and the solemnity of their covenant
It is a ritual to curse an enemy
It symbolizes Jonathan’s submission to David
It is a public political declaration
questions.correctAnswer: It expresses deep respect, affection, and the solemnity of their covenant
questions.explanation: The act of bowing and kissing (verse 41) reflects cultural expressions of respect and emotional bond, underscoring the seriousness of their covenantal farewell.

questions.question: True or False: Jonathan immediately suspects David of wrongdoing and refuses to help him when he seeks refuge in 1 Samuel 20.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jonathan assures David that his father will not seek to kill him without informing him (verse 2), showing Jonathan's trust and loyalty.

questions.question: What does the statement 'there is but a step between me and death' (1 Samuel 20:3) reveal about David’s psychological state and the theological motif of divine protection?
options: David feels immediate mortal danger and relies on God’s protection
David is confident in his own strength
David doubts Jonathan’s loyalty
David plans to confront Saul directly
questions.correctAnswer: David feels immediate mortal danger and relies on God’s protection
questions.explanation: David’s expression in verse 3 reveals his awareness of imminent danger, highlighting the motif of divine protection amid human threat.

questions.question: How does Jonathan’s role in 1 Samuel 20 exemplify the biblical theme of intercession and mediation between God’s people and rulers?
options: He mediates between David and Saul by seeking to inform David of Saul’s intentions
He directly rebels against Saul without caution
He abandons David to protect himself
He advises David to flee without further communication
questions.correctAnswer: He mediates between David and Saul by seeking to inform David of Saul’s intentions
questions.explanation: Jonathan acts as an intercessor (verses 12-13), attempting to discern Saul’s intentions and communicate them to David, reflecting the intercessory role in biblical narratives.

questions.question: In 1 Samuel 20:6, what is the significance of David’s proposed reason for leaving the king’s table to attend the yearly sacrifice in Bethlehem, in light of ancient Israelite religious customs?
options: It provides a legitimate religious excuse consistent with family obligations
It is a fabricated lie to deceive Saul
It is a political rally disguised as a sacrifice
It is irrelevant to the plot
questions.correctAnswer: It provides a legitimate religious excuse consistent with family obligations
questions.explanation: David’s excuse in verse 6 is culturally credible, as yearly sacrifices were important family religious events, making his absence plausible.

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 20 illustrate the theme of divine justice through the covenantal promise that Jonathan makes regarding David’s enemies?
options: Jonathan invokes the LORD to require justice from David’s enemies, showing trust in divine vindication
Jonathan plans to fight David’s enemies personally
Jonathan ignores the enemies, focusing only on David
Jonathan makes no reference to divine justice
questions.correctAnswer: Jonathan invokes the LORD to require justice from David’s enemies, showing trust in divine vindication
questions.explanation: Verse 16 shows Jonathan calling on the LORD to deal with David’s enemies, emphasizing reliance on divine justice rather than human vengeance.

questions.question: What literary parallelism exists between Jonathan’s covenantal oath and the final words in 1 Samuel 20:42, and what does it signify about the enduring nature of their bond?
options: Both invoke the LORD as a witness and establish a perpetual bond between their descendants
Both declare immediate political alliance for warfare
Both contain curses against Saul’s household
Both focus on Jonathan’s kingship
questions.correctAnswer: Both invoke the LORD as a witness and establish a perpetual bond between their descendants
questions.explanation: Verse 42 reiterates the covenant with the LORD as witness, extending the bond to their descendants, a parallel to earlier covenant language emphasizing enduring friendship.

theological.title: 1 Samuel Chapter 20 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Samuel Chapter 20 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What does 1 Samuel 20 reveal about Jonathan's attitude toward David when David fled to him?
options: Jonathan shows steadfast loyalty and covenant faithfulness to David
Jonathan betrays David to his father Saul immediately
Jonathan ignores David's plight
Jonathan advises David to flee without support
questions.correctAnswer: Jonathan shows steadfast loyalty and covenant faithfulness to David
questions.explanation: Jonathan makes a covenant with David (1 Samuel 20:16), loves him as his own soul (1 Samuel 20:17), and promises to protect him by warning him of Saul's intentions (1 Samuel 20:12-13). This demonstrates Jonathan's loyalty, which reflects biblical themes of covenant faithfulness found throughout Scripture (Genesis 9:9-17, Ruth 1:16-17, Proverbs 17:17, John 15:13).

questions.question: In 1 Samuel 20, what is the significance of the new moon in the narrative?
options: It marks the time when David would normally eat with King Saul
It is the time for a major battle
It signals the start of a famine
It is when Jonathan plans a feast for David
questions.correctAnswer: It marks the time when David would normally eat with King Saul
questions.explanation: David states he should not fail to sit with the king at meat during the new moon (1 Samuel 20:5). This timing is crucial for testing Saul's attitude toward David (1 Samuel 20:18-25). The new moon as a sacred time is consistent with biblical calendar observances (Numbers 28:11-15; Ezekiel 46:1; 2 Samuel 1:18).

questions.question: What does Jonathan propose as a sign to David regarding Saul's intentions toward him?
options: Shooting three arrows and sending a boy to retrieve them
Sending a messenger to warn David
Jonathan personally confronting Saul
David should stay hidden until Jonathan sends for him
questions.correctAnswer: Shooting three arrows and sending a boy to retrieve them
questions.explanation: Jonathan plans to shoot three arrows and send a boy to find them; depending on where the arrows fall, David will know if it is safe to return or if danger awaits (1 Samuel 20:19-22). This covert signaling reflects wisdom and care for David's life, aligning with biblical themes of protective friendship and divine providence (Psalm 91:3-7; Proverbs 27:17; Ecclesiastes 4:9-10).

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 20 portray Saul's disposition toward David after David's absence from the king's table?
options: Saul becomes angry and hostile, determined to kill David
Saul is indifferent and does not question David's absence
Saul is glad and wishes David well
Saul is confused but shows concern
questions.correctAnswer: Saul becomes angry and hostile, determined to kill David
questions.explanation: Saul's anger is kindled against Jonathan for supporting David (1 Samuel 20:30-31), and he orders Jonathan to bring David to him to be killed (1 Samuel 20:31). This reveals Saul's sinful jealousy and murderous intent, consistent with the biblical motif of the wicked ruler opposing God’s anointed (Psalm 2:1-3; Acts 4:25-26; Hebrews 11:32-34).

questions.question: What theological principle is highlighted by Jonathan's covenant with David in 1 Samuel 20?
options: The importance of covenant loyalty as reflecting God's faithfulness
The futility of human alliances
That political power is supreme over friendship
That divine promises are conditional on human effort
questions.correctAnswer: The importance of covenant loyalty as reflecting God's faithfulness
questions.explanation: Jonathan's covenant with David (1 Samuel 20:16) echoes God's unchanging faithfulness to His people (Deuteronomy 7:9; 2 Timothy 2:13; Lamentations 3:22-23). It underscores the biblical doctrine that human covenants mirror divine commitment, emphasizing trust and loyalty amid adversity.

questions.question: What does David’s question to Jonathan in 1 Samuel 20:1 reveal about human sin and divine justice?
options: David is confused about why he is being persecuted despite being innocent
David admits his guilt and seeks forgiveness
David plots revenge against Saul
David accepts his punishment without question
questions.correctAnswer: David is confused about why he is being persecuted despite being innocent
questions.explanation: David asks, 'What have I done?' showing the reality of undeserved suffering (1 Samuel 20:1). This reflects the biblical theme of the righteous suffering unjustly (Job 1:1; Psalm 73:3-17; 1 Peter 2:19-21), highlighting the tension between human sin, suffering, and God's ultimate justice.

questions.question: How does Jonathan’s response to David about Saul’s intentions demonstrate the attribute of God's providence?
options: Jonathan trusts that Saul will reveal his plans to him, showing God’s control over events
Jonathan believes Saul will always be hostile
Jonathan suggests fleeing without hope of reconciliation
Jonathan doubts God’s involvement in the matter
questions.correctAnswer: Jonathan trusts that Saul will reveal his plans to him, showing God’s control over events
questions.explanation: Jonathan says Saul will not do anything, great or small, without telling him (1 Samuel 20:2), indicating confidence in God’s providential oversight. This aligns with biblical teaching on God's sovereignty over human affairs (Proverbs 21:1; Romans 8:28; Psalm 37:23).

questions.question: What does the deep friendship between Jonathan and David symbolize in the broader biblical narrative?
options: The ideal of covenant brotherhood reflecting divine love
Political alliance for mutual gain
A temporary convenience in troubled times
A human relationship that ultimately fails
questions.correctAnswer: The ideal of covenant brotherhood reflecting divine love
questions.explanation: Jonathan loves David as his own soul and they swear to remain loyal (1 Samuel 20:17), symbolizing covenant brotherhood that reflects God's steadfast love (John 15:12-15; Ruth 1:16-17; 1 John 4:7-12). Their relationship models sacrificial friendship rooted in divine grace.

questions.question: What does David’s repeated oath to Jonathan in 1 Samuel 20 indicate about human responsibility before God?
options: That solemn oaths are binding and reflect reverence for God’s name
That oaths are unnecessary for true friendship
That God does not require human commitments
That oaths can be easily broken
questions.correctAnswer: That solemn oaths are binding and reflect reverence for God’s name
questions.explanation: David swears by the life of Jonathan and the LORD (1 Samuel 20:3; 20:17), demonstrating that oaths invoke God's presence and bear moral weight. This aligns with biblical injunctions on oaths (Ecclesiastes 5:4-5; Matthew 5:33-37; James 5:12).

questions.question: How does 1 Samuel 20 illustrate the theme of divine protection amid human hostility?
options: Jonathan acts as an instrument God uses to warn David, preserving his life
David is left to face Saul’s wrath alone
Jonathan sides with Saul against David
David flees without any divine indication
questions.correctAnswer: Jonathan acts as an instrument God uses to warn David, preserving his life
questions.explanation: Jonathan promises to inform David if Saul intends harm (1 Samuel 20:12-13), reflecting God's providential provision for His servants (Psalm 34:7; Isaiah 41:10; 2 Timothy 4:17). Jonathan is God’s means to protect David in the hostile environment.

questions.question: What does Saul’s reaction to Jonathan’s defense of David reveal about the nature of sin and its effect on relationships?
options: Sin breeds rebellion and division even within families
Sin strengthens family bonds
Sin leads to immediate repentance
Sin is easily forgiven in royal families
questions.correctAnswer: Sin breeds rebellion and division even within families
questions.explanation: Saul calls Jonathan a rebellious son and threatens to kill David (1 Samuel 20:30-31), showing how sin causes estrangement and conflict. This is consistent with biblical teaching on sin’s divisive effects (Genesis 4:8; Mark 3:25; James 4:1-4).

questions.question: How does the covenant between Jonathan and David relate to the eschatological promise of God's kingdom?
options: It anticipates the everlasting covenant and the future Davidic kingdom
It is only a temporary human agreement
It contradicts God's promise to Saul
It has no relation to God's kingdom promises
questions.correctAnswer: It anticipates the everlasting covenant and the future Davidic kingdom
questions.explanation: Jonathan’s covenant (1 Samuel 20:14-15, 42) reflects God’s promise that David's lineage will endure (2 Samuel 7:12-16; Isaiah 9:6-7; Luke 1:32-33), pointing forward to the Messianic kingdom fulfilled in Christ, the Son of David.

questions.question: What does the episode of David bowing and weeping with Jonathan in 1 Samuel 20 symbolize about human response to divine providence and friendship?
options: It reflects deep gratitude and the sacredness of covenant relationships under God
It shows weakness and despair
It is a mere formality with no spiritual meaning
It indicates final farewell without hope
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects deep gratitude and the sacredness of covenant relationships under God
questions.explanation: David bows and weeps with Jonathan (1 Samuel 20:41), demonstrating reverence, emotion, and commitment to their covenant under God’s sovereignty. This matches biblical expressions of worship, friendship, and covenant loyalty (Genesis 24:26-27; Ruth 1:9; John 11:35).

questions.question: What doctrine about God's justice and human suffering can be derived from David's experience in 1 Samuel 20?
options: The righteous may suffer persecution, but God’s justice ultimately prevails
The righteous never suffer
Suffering is always a punishment for sin
God is indifferent to human suffering
questions.correctAnswer: The righteous may suffer persecution, but God’s justice ultimately prevails
questions.explanation: David's near death experience despite innocence (1 Samuel 20:3) aligns with biblical teaching that the righteous suffer unjustly but God vindicates them (Psalm 37:1-9; 1 Peter 3:14-17; Romans 8:28; Revelation 21:4).

questions.question: How does the chapter 1 Samuel 20 depict the interplay between human free will and divine sovereignty?
options: Human choices, such as Saul’s hostility and Jonathan’s loyalty, occur under God's sovereign plan
Human actions are random and not influenced by God
God forces humans to act only in one way
Divine sovereignty negates human responsibility
questions.correctAnswer: Human choices, such as Saul’s hostility and Jonathan’s loyalty, occur under God's sovereign plan
questions.explanation: The narrative shows Saul’s anger and Jonathan’s covenant choices within God's providential control (1 Samuel 20:31; 20:42), consistent with biblical teaching that God governs human history while allowing moral responsibility (Proverbs 16:9; Acts 2:23; Philippians 2:12-13).

questions.question: What Christological foreshadowing can be identified in Jonathan’s protection of David in 1 Samuel 20?
options: Jonathan’s loyalty prefigures Christ’s intercession and protection of His people
Jonathan acts as an adversary like Saul
Jonathan’s covenant is unrelated to Christ
Jonathan replaces David as king
questions.correctAnswer: Jonathan’s loyalty prefigures Christ’s intercession and protection of His people
questions.explanation: Jonathan’s covenant love and protective warning (1 Samuel 20:16-22) prefigure Christ’s role as mediator and intercessor (Hebrews 7:25; Romans 8:34; John 17:9), demonstrating divine love securing the safety and salvation of the covenant community.
